Title: Farmer
Overview: Farmers and farm managers grow crops and raise livestock for food production.

EntryRouteSummary: You can get into this job through:a university course; a college course; an apprenticeship; working towards this role

RelevantSubjects: You could take a foundation degree, higher national diploma or degree in:agriculture; land management; farm business management; crop and livestock production
FurtherInformation: Courses and qualifications are available through [agricultural colleges | http://www.landex.org.uk/] as well as universities.
EntryRequirements: 1 or 2 A levels, or equivalent, for a foundation degree or higher national diploma
2 to 3 A levels, or equivalent, for a degree
AdditionalInformation: [student finance for fees and living costs | https://www.gov.uk/student-finance]

RelevantSubjects: You could start your career in farming by doing a course at agricultural college like:Level 2 Certificate in Land-based Activities; Level 3 Diploma in Agriculture
This would teach you some of the skills and knowledge needed in this job.
EntryRequirements: 2 or more GCSEs at grades 9 to 3 (A* to D), or equivalent, for a level 2 course
4 or 5 GCSEs at grades 9 to 4 (A* to C), or equivalent, for a level 3 course

RelevantSubjects: You can work towards this role through an advanced apprenticeship in agriculture.
This will usually take 18 months to complete. You'll do on-the-job training and spend time with a college or training provider.
You could do a higher apprenticeship in agricultural business management if you already have a lot of farming experience.
EntryRequirements: 5 GCSEs at grades 9 to 4 (A* to C) or equivalent, including English and maths, for an advanced apprenticeship
4 or 5 GCSEs at grades 9 to 4 (A* to C) and A levels, or equivalent, for a higher or degree apprenticeship

Work: You can get valuable experience and move into farm management by working as a supervisor, dairy or arable unit manager, or assistant manager.
You could also take qualifications on the job like the Level 4 Certificate in Work-based Agricultural Management.

FurtherInformation: You can find more on farming careers from [Tasty Careers | https://tastycareers.org.uk/job-descriptions?keywords=&tags=agriculture&category=true&page=2] and the [National Land Based College | https://nlbc.uk/careers/land-based-careers/].

WhatItTakes.DigitalSkillsLevel: to be able to carry out basic tasks on a computer or hand-held device

Skills.Description: the ability to work well with others
to be thorough and pay attention to detail
physical skills like movement, coordination, dexterity and grace
excellent verbal communication skills
thinking and reasoning skills
the ability to work on your own
patience and the ability to remain calm in stressful situations
the ability to work well with your hands
to be flexible and open to change
the ability to think clearly using logic and reasoning
the ability to monitor your own performance and that of your colleagues
leadership skills
observation and recording skills
the ability to operate and control equipment
business management skills
customer service skills
concentration skills
knowledge of manufacturing production and processes
knowledge of biology
the ability to use, repair and maintain machines and tools

WYDDayToDayTasks: Your day-to-day tasks may include:planning how the farm will run; setting budget and production targets; buying and selling animals or produce; keeping financial and stock records; recruiting, training and supervising staff

WorkingEnvironment.Location: You could work in an office or on a farm.
WorkingEnvironment.Environment: Your working environment may be outdoors in all weathers.
WorkingEnvironment.Uniform: You may need to wear protective clothing.

CareerPathAndProgression: With experience, you could move into related areas, like agricultural advisory work for government bodies, consultancy or training.
